channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Right-Wing Groups Are Organizing on Telegram Ahead of Election Day
item.description: Right-wing groups, which use Telegram to organize real-world actions, are urging followers to watch the polls and stand up for their rights, in a harbinger of potential chaos.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur, Adam Satariano, Aaron Krolik and Steven Lee Myers
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Telegram played a small but significant role in the 2020 election as an organizing tool for planners of the Jan. 6 attack.

item.title: How Elon Musk’s X Account Dominates the Platform Ahead of the Election
item.description: The billionaire has effectively become the star of his social media platform, transforming X into a reflection of his personal views before the election.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger, Aaron Krolik, Santul Nerkar and Dylan Freedman
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie/The New York Times
item.media:description: Elon Musk, who owns X, has posted more than 3,000 times on the site in the last month.

item.title: Nvidia Will Replace Intel in the Dow Jones Stock Index
item.description: The change, starting next Friday, lifts a dominant player in artificial intelligence over its chip-making rival, which has struggled to keep up.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Nvidia’s market value of $3.32 trillion has far surpassed Intel’s.

item.title: Meta Permits Its A.I. Models to Be Used for U.S. Military Purposes
item.description: The shift in policy, covering government agencies and contractors working on national security, is intended to promote “responsible and ethical” innovations, the company said.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, in September. Meta supports open-source artificial intelligence models that other developers, companies and governments can freely copy and distribute.

item.title: 5 Reasons Early Voting Is Overwhelmed With Election Misinformation
item.description: Misleading anecdotes and rumors are spreading faster, and with more ferocity, than in the run-ups to past presidential contests.
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times
item.media:description: More states have embraced early voting and mail-in voting since 2020, inadvertently creating the kind of tense and confusing exchanges that spread wildly online before the facts are known.

item.title: New York Times Tech Workers Go on Strike
item.description: The Times Tech Guild represents more than 600 software developers and others who run the back-end systems behind The Times’s digital operation.
item.dc:creator: Katie Robertson
item.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: Union workers outside The New York Times building on Monday.

item.title: No, Vote Spikes on Election Night Do Not Indicate Voter Fraud
item.description: The false claim, which has circulated in recent elections, is based on a misunderstanding of how votes are collected and reported.
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: How a Georgia Security Conference Became a Target of Election Deniers
item.description: The gathering had nothing to do with the election. That didn’t stop conspiracy theorists from spreading falsehoods.
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paul Wertz, a 61-year-old former paramedic and Navy reservist in Roswell, Ga., has organized security conferences since 2020.

item.title: This Group Refuses to Stop Tracking Disinformation
item.description: Though a larger coalition of fact checkers has disbanded, a team of students and researchers at the University of Washington in Seattle is still working to document how lies online threaten to undermine this year’s presidential race.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:credit: Chona Kasinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Four years ago, researchers at the University of Washington were part of a larger coalition formed to combat claims by President Donald J. Trump and others that the 2020 election was rigged. Now, that coalition has disbanded.

item.title: Billionaire Game Theory + We Are Not Ready for A.G.I. + Election Betting Markets Get Weird
item.description: “If I had $1 billion, how would I try to influence the results of this election?”
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Whitney Jones, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Chris Wood, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Diane Wong
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Photo: Clodagh Kilcoyne/Reuters

item.title: What if A.I. Is Actually Good for Hollywood?
item.description: It’s already powering remarkable visual innovations, like in the new movie “Here.” But boosters think that’s just the beginning.
item.dc:creator: Devin Gordon

item.title: Apple’s Quarterly Profit Down Because of Tax Payment in Europe
item.description: Sales for the iPhone maker were up 6 percent to to $94.93 billion. But a $14.4 billion tax bill cut profits that would have topped expectations.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Amy Osborne for The New York Times
item.media:description: Apple’s delay with A.I. didn’t slow down its business

item.title: Intel Posts $16.6 Billion Quarterly Loss, Its Biggest Ever
item.description: The Silicon Valley chip maker has struggled to turn around its fortunes after missing opportunities and poor execution.
item.dc:creator: Don Clark
item.media:credit: Anastasiia Sapon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Intel said its loss for the third quarter totaled $16.6 billion.

item.title: Elon Musk’s xAI in Funding Talks That Could Value Company at $40 Billion
item.description: The financing efforts follow that of rival OpenAI, which recently closed a funding round that valued it at $157 billion.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac and Cade Metz
item.media:credit: David Swanson/Reuters
item.media:description: Elon Musk’s xAI could be valued at as much as $40 billion, although financing talks are in the early stages.

item.title: OpenAI Launches ChatGPT Search Engine
item.description: The popular online chatbot can now access and deliver information from across the internet in real time, including news, stock prices and sports scores.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.media:credit: OpenAI
item.media:description: The new search engine is available beginning today for people who use ChatGPT Plus.

item.title: Why a Memphis Community Is Fighting Elon Musk’s Supercomputer
item.description: Residents say Mr. Musk’s data center for artificial intelligence is compounding their pollution burden and adding stress on the local electrical grid.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Kate Conger
item.media:credit: Whitten Sabbatini for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scale of potential power consumption from an xAI supercomputer center meant the plan required approval from the Tennessee Valley Authority, which operates the electric grid for much of the region.

item.title: Election Falsehoods Take Off on YouTube as It Looks the Other Way
item.description: The video site removed 2020 misinformation, fearing real-world harm. Now it’s amplifying and profiting from 2024 falsehoods, researchers said.
item.dc:creator: Nico Grant

item.title: Meta Earnings Show Revenue Increase, Even as Spending Spree Continues
item.description: The Silicon Valley company, which owns Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp, said it does not plan to slow down its investments anytime soon.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Meta’s Meta Quest headset. The company reported double-digit revenue and profit growth for the third quarter.

item.title: Microsoft Earnings Show Quarterly Revenue Is Up 16% to $65.6 Billion
item.description: The company’s profit increased 11 percent to $24.7 billion, beating Wall Street’s expectations and its own predictions.
item.dc:creator: Karen Weise
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
item.media:description: Surface notebooks, powered by artificial intelligence, at a Microsoft event in May. The company has bet heavily on A.I. through its investments in OpenAI.

item.title: Nishad Singh, a Top FTX Executive, Is Given No Prison Time After Cooperation
item.description: Mr. Singh, who was a top executive in Sam Bankman-Fried’s business empire, had pleaded guilty to fraud and campaign finance violations that contributed to the collapse of FTX.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Kaye and David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nishad Singh, a former top executive of the FTX crypto exchange, left, and Claire Watanabe, who also worked at FTX, arriving at federal court in Manhattan on Wednesday.

item.title: Kraken Lays Off 15% of Workers and Names Arjun Sethi New Co-CEO
item.description: The influential cryptocurrency exchange has undergone several reorganizations in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac, David Yaffe-Bellany and Ryan Mac
item.media:credit: Ramsey Cardy/Sportsfile for Collision, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Kraken named Arjun Sethi, a longtime Silicon Valley executive, as co-chief executive.

item.title: Jeff Bezos, Elon Musk and the Billions of Ways to Influence an Election
item.description: The world’s richest men have their own rocket fleets, their own media and their own schemes to succeed with Donald J. Trump.
item.dc:creator: David Streitfeld
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times, Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeff Bezos and Elon Musk have taken different approaches to the presidential election, with varying results.

item.title: Three Mile Island Is at the Center of Efforts to Expand Nuclear Capacity to Meet Rising Power Demand
item.description: The Pennsylvania plant, site of the worst U.S. nuclear energy accident, is at the forefront of efforts to expand nuclear capacity to meet rising electricity demand.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott and George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cooling towers at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant in Pennsylvania, where Constellation Energy plans to restart a reactor it shut down in 2019.

item.title: How FTX’s Young Executives Shattered Their Parents
item.description: As their children are sentenced for fraud, the parents of FTX’s top leaders have described their disbelief at how the crypto exchange upended their lives.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sam Bankman-Fried’s parents, Joseph Bankman and Barbara Fried, are part of a group of parents who wrote letters pleading for leniency for their children involved in the FTX case.

item.title: Alphabet Revenue Jumps 15% to $88.3 Billion
item.description: The tech giant’s 34 percent increase in quarterly profit topped Wall Street expectations, driven by its advertising and cloud businesses.
item.dc:creator: Nico Grant
item.media:credit: Amy Osborne/The New York Times
item.media:description: Alphabet, the parent company of Google, continued making large investments in data centers, chips and other hardware in the third quarter.

item.title: Trump Family Members and Biden Aides Among China Hack Targets
item.description: Phones used by Jared Kushner and Eric Trump were among those that hackers sought access to as part of a counterintelligence effort carried out by a hacking group associated with China.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett, Ben Protess and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Eric Trump was one of those believed to have been targeted by Chinese hackers.

item.title: TSMC Chips Ended Up in Devices Made by China’s Huawei Despite U.S. Controls
item.description: The U.S. government has tried to keep Chinese companies from obtaining certain advanced technologies, but concerns have been growing that some products may have been routed to Huawei.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin, Ana Swanson, John Liu and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Alex Plavevski/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The Huawei store in Shanghai. The U.S. government has blocked Huawei from buying products made with American technology.

item.title: G.M.’s Electric Vehicle Sales Surge as Ford Loses Billions
item.description: Ford is struggling to make money on battery-powered models while General Motors, which started more slowly, says it is getting close to that goal.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.category: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks
item.media:credit: David Walter Banks for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ford’s F-150 Lightning truck beat the Tesla Cybertruck to the market by more than a year.

item.title: How a Data Center Divided a Small Missouri Town
item.description: Residents of Peculiar battled developers and some of their local officials to keep a giant data center out of their community.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan and Graham Dickie
item.media:description: Chad Buck, rear center, in a prayer circle with his family on land that was slated to be developed into a data center.
